titleStmt.title: Stretched Skulls: Anamorphic Games and the Memento Mortem Mortis

dhq:bio.p: Stephanie Boluk is a recent graduate from the Department of English at the University of Florida and is now completing a postdoctoral fellowship in the Media Studies program at Vassar College. For more information please visit http://stephanieboluk.com

Patrick LeMieux is an artist and Ph.D. student in the Department of Art, Art History, and Visual Studies at Duke University. He has exhibited artwork in the Tampa Museum of Art, FSU Museum of Fine Arts, the Samuel P. Harn Museum of Art, and his latest artwork, Open House, was featured at SIGGRAPH 2011. For more information please visit http://patrick-lemieux.com

dhq:abstract.p: From Hans Holbein’s The Ambassadors to Robert Lazzarini’s skulls, anamorphic artworks explore the tension between mathematical models of vision and more fully embodied models of subjectivity. After reviewing the ways in which anamorphosis has been deployed as a philosophical tool for examining this relationship between technology and phenomenology, specifically via the criticism of Espen Aarseth and Mark Hansen, this paper analyzes how contemporary videogames like Sony’s Echochrome series, levelHead by Julian Oliver, and Mark ten Bosch’s forthcoming Miegakure technically, aesthetically, and conceptually explore anamorphic techniques. Historically, anamorphosis has been deployed as a memento mori, but we propose that games which frame anamorphosis as a metaphor for technology can be more accurately described as memento mortem mortis: reminders of a space beyond the death of death. Anamorphic games gesture towards fields of experience altogether indifferent to the human and foreground the radical alterity of computational logics to create allegories of the beyond. The result is that these are not so much speculative games, as they are games of speculation.

div.head: The Myth of Mimesis

figure.head: The Origin of Painting: Dibutades Tracing the Portrait of a Shepherd (1785), by Jean-Baptiste Regnault.

div.p: In Naturalis Historia (c. AD 77-79), Pliny the Elder recounts two myths of mimetic representation. In one, the daughter of the Corinthian sculptor Butades, saddened by the imminent departure of her lover, traces the outline of his shadow as it is cast on a wall (see Figure 1) . Inspired by this image, Butades presses clay over the drawing to sculpt a relief portrait based on the silhouette. This myth, which binds drawing and sculpting, does not celebrate the originality or expressivity of the artist’s hand but instead focuses on the possibility of an indexical relationship between light, sight, and representation: an ancient camera activated by the hand of Butades’ daughter. Elsewhere in his Naturalis Historia, Pliny recites another well-known myth: the story of Zeuxis and Parrhasius who compete to determine the best painter . Zeuxis paints grapes that look so natural, birds fly down to peck at them, but Parrhasius bests Zeuxis by painting curtains that deceive the other painter so completely that Zeuxis asks to draw the curtains aside to reveal the artwork he believes they conceal.

The desire for mimetic representation and the development of image-making technologies have progressed from the ancient legend of Butades’ lovelorn daughter tracing shadows to Renaissance-era techniques of tracing light through panes of glass to contemporary ray tracing, a technique for rendering computer graphics (see Figure 2). Deeply wedded to historical theories of light, what joins these separate methods is their focus on the human body as a cycloptic camera lens, an abstract optic perfectly positioned to decode perspectival data.

figure.head: Man Drawing a Lute (1525) by Albrecht Dürer and a typical example of ray tracing.

div.p: But what if the sun had begun to set on Butades’ daughter, transforming her lover’s silhouette into a monstrous grotesque? Or if Zeuxis had approached Parrhasius’ painted curtains from an oblique angle, disrupting the two-dimensional illusion of depth? If Albrecht Dürer’s glass veil had been bumped askew or the algorithms responsible for rendering 3D space were not calibrated properly, would the difference be noticeable or is optical distortion a precondition for mimetic representation? Once the rules of naturalism have been established, it is inevitable that artists, architects, and illustrators alike will seek to break or re-write the codes of perspectival rendering. This potential for experimentation applies as much to the anamorphic techniques employed by early painters as it does to the strange, polygonal environments traversed in virtual worlds. Many recent developments in graphical realism are converging around the computer graphics industry whose design goals and business models largely conform to the possibilities and problems of mimetic technologies. Much like the restrained naturalism of Renaissance perspectival rendering led to a more self-conscious and reflexive Mannerist period of visual art, so have the nascent discourses surrounding computer generated imagery (CGI) and videogaming begun to internalize and amplify their codes and logics. As John Carmack recently noted at the 2011 Electronic Entertainment Expo (E3), computer graphics are converging at the limits of our biological systems . The videogame industry is evolving asymptotically toward higher and higher graphic fidelity, and there are only a finite number of unique polygons and pixels perceptible to the human eye. With graphical realism approaching the threshold of human perception, there are an increasing number of computer games experimenting with alternative spatial and optical regimes indigenous to digital environments.

This paper begins with a review of how anamorphosis has been deployed as a philosophical tool for exploring the relationship between human phenomenology and technology. Anamorphosis is a perspectival rendering technique that produces warped but geometrically viable images. From Hans Holbein the Younger’s The Ambassadors to Robert Lazzarini’s skulls, anamorphic artworks explore the tension between mathematical models of vision (that reduce sight to a single, abstract locus) and more dispersed models of subjective vision which account for both the human body and its relation to an environment. This tension is made explicit in the 3D modeling and real-time graphic processing of computers. Extending the arguments of media theorists Espen Aarseth and Mark Hansen, we analyze how anamorphosis functions in contemporary videogames. Games like Sony’s Echochrome series, levelHead by Julian Oliver, and Mark ten Bosch’s forthcoming Miegakure employ anamorphosis as a metaphor for technology, marking dissonant registers of time and space produced between computational processes and the human body. By attempting to represent the alterity of computational logics, these anamorphic games remind the player of the limits of human phenomenology and create gameplay from the desire to think the unthinkable and to play in spaces that exceed the boundaries of human perception.

div.head: Memento Mortem Mortis
div.p: Anamorphosis is a perspectival rendering technique popularized during the Renaissance which results in a strangely stretched, but geometrically viable image requiring a human viewer to assume an oblique viewing angle in order to uncover its encrypted images. While Erwin Panofsky famously claimed in 1927 that traditional perspective operated as a symbolic form, loaded with the Western ontology of the stable, fixed, and unified Cartesian subject, anamorphosis has remained a marginal visual technique, a trompe l’oeil that operates according to a different cultural logic, stealthily putting pressure on the universality of classical perspective and all the attendant ideological assumptions surrounding this symbolic form . More recently, the concept of anamorphosis has appeared in the writing of media theorists such as Espen Aarseth and Mark Hansen. In these texts, anamorphosis is treated as a tool for examining the discontinuities between biological and computational registers via the discussion of re-embodied vision.

Traditionally, the techniques of geometrical projection employed in perspectival rendering assume the position of the viewer as directly in front of and oriented toward the picture plane, an imaginary field that typically coincides with the material surface of an image. Conflating this picture plane with the geometry of canvas allows the simulated light vectors of a given geometric projection to intersect with a material plane rather than a purely virtual surface. This conflation removes the need for difficult, higher level modeling and simplifies the rendering process considerably. The geometry of an anamorphic image, however, produces nonstandard viewing angles by foreshortening this picture plane and decoupling it from the physical geometry of the canvas, screen, or parchment. An experimental and unconventional technique which produces coded, mannered, and seemingly non-natural imagery, anamorphosis is often regarded as a curiosity, an occasional virtuosic supplement to the catalogue of classical perspective throughout the history of art. But if one acknowledges the fact that any historical coincidence of the imaginary picture plane and the material surface of a painting is merely one particular case within a much larger field of possibility, anamorphosis can be re-thought as the rule, rather than the exception to perspectival image making. In a sense, every image is already anamorphic though ease of rendering and conventions of human sight privilege one particular, historically contingent instance of anamorphosis: perspective.

Though anamorphic images explicitly reinforce the relationship between vision and embodiment through the construction of perspectival spaces that appear to resolve only at nonstandard vantage points and viewing angles (compelling the subject to configure her body to the painting’s unusual constraints), there is a more profound critique of Cartesian subjectivity at work in this optical technique. Anamorphosis foregrounds the impossibility of a perfectly resolved image (including those constructed according to the rules of classical perspective) given the biological complexity of binocular vision, angle of approach, height of the subject, and surface deformations of the media. These anamorphic biases demonstrate that what has been culturally defined as classical perspective remains an essentially arbitrary method of rendering light through mathematical abstractions that are impossible to realize on the parts of both viewer and painter. Whether standing in front of a painting or grasping a controller, embodied vision is made anamorphic through haptic encounters with the material environment.

The quintessential example of anamorphosis is Hans Holbein’s The Ambassadors, a large and meticulously rendered oil painting featuring a strange, anamorphic smear across the bottom of the otherwise typical portrait of two sixteenth-century European diplomats (see Figure 3). The men stand costumed and well-lit in a carefully proportioned, perspectival space, each with an elbow resting on the foreshortened table. The painting displays a menagerie of symbolic details denoting worldly opulence including fine clothing and foreign textiles, a lute with a book of open sheet music, two globes, and various instruments for navigation and cartography: instruments of rationalism that will provide the correct perspective for mapping the New World. Yet, if the viewer examines the painting from an unorthodox position below and to the right of the standard viewing angle, the smear congeals into a grinning skull: a subliminal memento mori hidden in plain sight.It has been suggested that the portrait was originally hung at the top of a staircase and that glimpses of the skull could be caught upon approaching the painting from the bottom left. Turning around upon descending the staircase would also reveal a concealed skull.

figure.head: Hans Holbein’s The Ambassadors and a detail of the resolved anamorphic skull.

div.p: While the inclusion of subtle reminders of mortality like skulls, time pieces, wilting flowers, or rotting fruit were common among portraits and still lifes produced in medieval and Renaissance Europe, Holbein’s memento mori is particularly unsettling given its uncanny manifestation through the technique of anamorphic foreshortening. As Jacques Lacan writes in the Four Fundamental Concepts of Psychoanalysis, the anamorphic distortion gives access to a dimension that has nothing to do with vision as such - something symbolic of the function of the lack . Read psychoanalytically, Holbein’s anamorphic skull is a trap for the gaze into which the subject disappears. Lacan ultimately concludes his chapter not by distinguishing anamorphosis from traditional perspective, but by arguing that it demonstrates what is implicit in all image production (and by extension the concept of a stable Cartesian subject): In any picture, it is precisely in seeking the gaze in each of its points that you will see it disappear .

Lacan’s reading of the painting acknowledges the idea that Holbein’s anamorphic skull is powerful not because it looks like a skull, but precisely because it doesn’t look like a skull. It is a not-skull - a not-skull revealing nothing to the viewer but paint. Though it has the potential to trick the eye, this smear of abject materiality bears no formal resemblance to human anatomy and exists within its own ontological register. Holbein’s choice of the skull as representational content further supports this idea. Working with the established cultural tradition of the memento mori, the artist summons notions of death’s alterity as a metaphor for the ultimate strangeness of paint. The fleeting glimpse of a death’s head, reminds the viewer not of their eventual expiration, but - perhaps an even more unsettling reminder - of the fact that there exist inaccessible objects in the world that exceed human legibility. The anamorphic skull suggests a world that not only lies beyond the limitations of the human body, but one that is also completely disinterested in the affairs of man and the vagaries of life and death.

In this respect, it may be more accurate to use the term memento mortem mortis than memento mori. The memento mortem mortis transforms the human-centred remembrance of death into the remembrance of the death of death: the realization that one day even death will die. The painterly materiality of the anamorphic skull ultimately exposes a notion of cosmic indifference that is vaster, more alien, and more terrifying than even the anthropocentric concerns of life and death represented through a memento mori. The stretched skull, like other depictions of human detritus, has been used to signal human mortality. But by rendering it on a separate, foreshortened picture plane that refuses to cohere with the geometry of the painted scene, this memento mori opens upon the yawning abyss of the memento mortem.

This paper reads anamorphosis as a form of memento mortem mortis. In anamorphic images, the subject and object never completely resolve for one another, and there remains an incommensurable gap as reflected in Holbein’s painting. In this sense, the human and the skull can never see eye to eye, and The Ambassadors functions as an allegory for deanthropomorphized materiality in the idiom of early-modern painting. Hubert Damisch has argued that mathematical perspective has been the dominant mode of image-making in the twentieth century (far more than previous eras prior to the development of mechanical forms of image inscription such as photography, film, and video ). Yet this traditional perspective can still be regarded as just a special case of anamorphosis: projected from one point on an infinite spectrum adapted to generalized angles and eyelines of the human body. All paintings are anamorphic in so far as they apply the rules of perspectival projection to an arbitrary, anthropocentric picture plane. The coincidence of the picture plane and material surface of the image is popular because of the convenience of calculating only one projection, rather than the multiple abstractions necessary in anamorphosis. Developing alongside this technology, the culture of perspective reinforces the status until it appears natural to the human viewer despite the fact that perspectival rendering still requires those same mathematical systems of geometric projection used to construct any anamorphic image. Thus, all paintings could be considered anamorphic, but only some, like The Ambassadors, form a memento mortem mortis to explicitly question the necessary relation between the human body, an image’s material support, and the virtual geometries of the perspectival picture plane.

div.head: Ergodic Resolution
div.p: For media theorists like Espen Aarseth and Mark Hansen, anamorphosis functions as a useful model for framing their theories of digital media. Aarseth and Hansen adopt two contrasting approaches. Whereas Aarseth uses anamorphosis to speak about what he calls ergodic literature and operates from the assumption that anamorphic objects include a correct location or perspective from which to view an image, Hansen uses anamorphosis as a model for describing those aspects of digital media that fail to resolve and which produce a bodily tension based on the formal incongruity between inhabitable space and computational space.

Espen Aarseth’s Cybertext: Perspectives on Ergodic Literature is a highly influential work of media criticism and an early entry into the nascent field of game studies. Using a variety of examples taken from print, computer games, hypertext, and electronic literature, Aarseth builds a working theory of ergodic literature, his term for literary works whose completion requires nontrivial effort on the part of the reader . By nontrivial effort, Aarseth means the kinetic as well as intellectual effort performed by a reader or player that specifically functions to influence the outcome of a given text or game (this is distinct, for example, from flipping to the end of a book to read the final pages). If we consider Aarseth’s model in relation to Holbein’s skull, bending low to the ground in an effort to match the oblique angle of anamorphic distortion is similar to Aarseth’s notion of ergodic, nontrivial labor. This effort required of a viewer of anamorphic images is what leads Aarseth to make an analogy between early modern techniques of anamorphosis and certain forms of interactive media.

In the concluding chapter of Cybertext, Aarseth suggests that anamorphosis is a solvable enigma . For Aarseth, the key quality of anamorphosis is the moment of revelation produced when the distortion of the warped image is suddenly resolved through the viewer’s effort of locating the vantage point from which the rational order of classical perspective is restored. It is this passage from what he terms aporia to epiphany by which he conflates anamorphic painting with ergodic literature . For Aarseth, the text-based games and interactive fiction of the late seventies and early eighties such as Will Crowther and Don Woods’ Colossal Cave Adventure (1975–76) and Infocom's Zork trilogy (1980–84) are models of an anamorphic textuality in which the player must work in order for the mystery to be revealed.

But not all ergodic texts provide puzzles with seemingly concrete answers and Aarseth invents a second category he terms metamorphosis in which mastery and resolution are refused (e.g. Michael Joyce’s Afternoon: A Story [1987]). This article proposes, however, that there is no need for a second category in which to reroute those texts which do not have singular interpretations, linear causality, or solvable enigmas. As argued in the previous section, rather than reifying a specific subject position in front of a painting, image, or artifact, the anamorphic technique radically critiques all subject positions as tenuous and fraught. Even if there is a viewing angle in which an image becomes discernible, this angle is no more correct than any other and any resolution the viewer might feel is automatically suspect. The anamorphic skull in The Ambassadors (1553) is not a memento mori in the sense that it reminds the viewer of her mortality as she catches a glimpse of the skull through the corner of her eye, but because it calls into question the very concept of a fixed subject and resolved object. The logic of the stretched skull, the memento mortem mortis, suggests that the subject herself is distributed, deferred, and derealized in the same way the anamorphic image smears across the canvas.

div.head: Strange Skulls
div.p: In New Philosophy for New Media Mark Hansen also relates anamorphosis to contemporary digital media practice. For Hansen, however, it is the failure of anamorphic images to be easily digested by the human body which he finds relevant to digital forms. Hansen uses Robert Lazzarini’s sculptural installation skulls, exhibited at the Whitney Museum of American Art’s 2000 show BitStreams, as his central case study in order to explain the relationship between digital media and anamorphosis (see Figure 4). Like Hans Holbein and other Renaissance painters who practiced anamorphic techniques, Robert Lazzarini’s artwork engages with the limits of human perception, systems of perspectival projection, and the essential tension produced between these two orders. Instead of projecting smears of paint across picture planes, a purely visual puzzle, Lazzarini builds smeared sculptures which stretch in three-dimensions and challenge the viewer to reconcile vision and proprioception. Where anamorphosis renders perspectival imagery onto a foreshortened picture plane, Lazzarini’s sculptural process involves applying perspectival effects directly to the geometry of a set of haptic objects.
Figure 4. A photograph of one of Robert Lazzarini’s skulls.

A critical component of Lazzarini’s practice is his choice of what to sculpt. Though the artist’s thoroughly digitized development process - starting by 3D laser-scanning each object to produce editable polygonal models then bending, warping, shifting, and deforming each file before finally crafting each rapidly prototyped outcome from authentic materials - remains relatively consistent throughout his catalogue of sculptures, each is selected to produce cognitive tension between the physical materiality of the sculpture and a particular perceptual effect . The subject matter and materials of Lazzarini’s process change from skulls to violins, hammers, teacups, telephones (and telephone booths), chairs, knives, revolvers, and brass knuckles. These household objects and weapons share one thing in common aside from Lazzarini’s anamorphic effects: an ergonomic reference to the human body. It is only through this remarkable tension between optic and haptic that Lazzarini’s sculptures become tools from another digital dimension, hammers with ungraspable handles.

In Tool-Being: Heidegger and the Metaphysics of Objects , Graham Harman re-imagines Martin Heidegger’s philosophy of objects, examining the commonly received understanding of Heidegger’s concept of present-at-hand and ready-to-hand objects. Harman proposes that implicit in Heidegger’s thinking is a far more radical ontology of objects themselves than has been traditionally assumed and builds his object-oriented ontology around the idea that objects have a kind of secret life in which they withdraw from human view into a dark subterranean reality that never becomes present to practical action any more than it does to theoretical awareness . With Lazzarini’s sculptures, the viewer experiences the chasm between herself and the inaccessible tool-being of objects. Anamorphosis functions as a metaphor for a speculative ontology as Lazzarini sculpts objects that literally appear to recede from our vision. These objects gesture towards a world beyond life and death (and even undeath).

Yet amongst this myriad of digitally disfigured tools, skulls stands apart. The sculpture does not have the same status as a hammer that cannot be held or wielded. There is a certain irony to the fact that skulls maintains a kind of functionality: the fact that viewers cannot fix their gaze on a stable optical regime only intensifies the skulls’ role as a memento mori. Technically, it does what it is supposed to do: it enables the (philosophical and contemplative) work such objects are typically designed to generate. Harman writes that there is an absolute gulf between the things and any interaction we might have with them which exists with respect to all objects. The optical instability of Lazzarini’s sculptures draws attention to this fact, yet it still reinscribes the centrality of human perception. This is perhaps why Mark Hansen chose skulls as emblematic of the profoundly alienating condition of the digital in New Philosophy for New Media. Lazzarini’s skulls shift focus away from the ergonomic, hand-held common objects to the forms of the body itself. Looming in life-scale, carved in bone, yet digitally modeled, skulls renders one of the most visually recognizable parts of human anatomy strange and uncanny. What provided a fleeting glimpse into the Real for Lacan, is used by Hansen to demonstrate the incommensurable ontology of a computer.

div.head: The Digital Any-Space-Whatever
div.p: In a chapter titled The Affective Topology of New Media, Hansen argues that Lazzarini’s adaptation of the anamorphic skull from Holbein’s Ambassadors is exemplary of digital media art . Lazzarini’s sculptures exist physically within three-dimensional space and yet, no matter what angle the distorted objects are viewed from, they fail to visually resolve in a satisfying way. Their hollow eyes refuse to stare back. Viewers of these uncanny objects inhabit a space completely at odds with the skulls which remain inaccessible and inassimilable to standard optical perspective. If one could close her eyes and hold Lazzarini’s stretched skulls, the contours might resolve to the haptic touch, but as Hansen writes, skulls makes sense visually - only within the weird logic and topology of the computer . In this sense, skulls picks up where The Ambassadors left off, signaling the existence of a nonhuman realm external to embodied perception and simultaneously challenging the ocularcentrism of the Cartesian subject by reinforcing a mutual, albeit dissonant, relation between eye and touch.

Holbein’s use of anamorphosis re-directs attention away from mathematical models of vision by emphasizing the contingency of sight on a viewer’s specific bodily relation to an image (and when conceived as a memento mori, the radical contingency of life in general). Similarly, skulls challenges notions of frictionless immersivity and the desire for intuitive, natural, or, as Apple advertises, magic interfaces that attempt to render human-computer interaction invisible. In spite of this history of user-friendly interface design, Lazzarini offers an optical distortion designed to disrupt, rather than pacify, the senses. Instead of appealing to the fantasy of immersion, anamorphic technologies delight in the fact that perspective can never be fully realized to the embodied viewer. Lazzarini’s sculptures, according to Hansen, produce a bodily experience of what he terms the digital any-space-whatever (digital ASW), a proprioceptive experience akin to nausea or vertigo as the body fails to orient itself. Hansen writes that in the face of skulls you feel the space around you begin to ripple, to bubble, to infold…and you notice an odd tensing in your gut, as if your viscera were itself trying to adjust to this warped space . This physical response recalls Slavoj Žižek’s description of the Lacanian Real as the pulsing of the pre-symbolic substance in all its abhorrent vitality .

Hansen’s term for this unsettling bodily awareness, the digital ASW, is based on Gilles Deleuze’s cinematic any-space-whatever (ASW) discussed in Cinema 1 . Deleuze’s cinematic ASW was an attempt to describe the empty, dislocated spaces of post-war cinema and distinguish them from the Hollywood logic of pre-war film. What is foregrounded, in both Deleuze’s and Hansen’s version of the ASW, is not the visual perception of this space, but the effects produced on the body. The key difference between the digital ASW and Deleuze’s theory is that because it must be forged out of contact with a radically inhuman realm, the digital ASW lacks an originary contact with the space of human activity . As such, the digital ASW emerges within the body when the viewer comes in contact with the impossible physics and unconventional perspectives of computational space. Hansen argues that [w]hat skulls affords is, consequently, not a direct apprehension of an alien space that is digital, but a bodily apprehension of just how radically alien the formal field of the computer is . In a famous scene from The Matrix (1999), a character named Cypher comments I don't even see the code. All I see is blonde, brunette, red-head (a feat which simultaneously exceeds human optical processing power and posits an indexical relationship between code and representation). The desire to see through the code is conflated with a voyeuristic pleasure in women's bodies. By contrast, Lazzarini’s art substitutes eros for thanatos in a process that forecloses any fetishized fantasy of access. A viewer’s encounter with his computational space produces only a heightened sense of the bodily alterity and unreadability of digital landscapes.

Following Hansen’s argument, videogames, like all digital media, are built upon formal fields only interpretable by computers. Effectively barring the human agent from ever achieving full access, the incongruity of computational and biological forms of space and time produces an embodied and affective response in the human: Hansen’s digital ASW. This is a response, however, that most game designers attempt to mitigate. While a work like skulls emphasizes the failure of the viewer to grasp these forever skewed and uncanny objects, videogames do not generally make a practice of cultivating sensory discomfort as such a game is unlikely to gain a large audience or be commercially viable. While a novice player may find the side-scrolling environments of a game like Super Mario Bros. (1985) uncanny and baffling, the goal of Shigeru Miyamoto and Nintendo’s developers has always been to create worlds in which the spatial and temporal mechanics can be quickly apprehended and then taken for granted in order to engage in other, more digestible operations.

For example, two-dimensional spatializations such as moving left to right (as one might read English or advance forward in the first quadrant of a Cartesian grid) or climbing from the bottom of the screen toward the top were exploited by and reinforced in early arcade games and influenced Nintendo’s original titles. However, in The Legend Of Zelda (1986), it is only custom and visual literacy that prevents a player from thinking that the player’s avatar, Link, is not floating through a 2D space, a gravityless version of Super Mario Bros. In Legend of Zelda, rather than assuming the perspective of a side-scrolling cross section, the horizontal and vertical axes correspond to the cardinal directions of an orthographic, bird’s-eye view map. Link’s movement is multi-directional, a significant feat at the time allowing him to walk North, South, East, and West rather than forward, backward, up, and down. While there is nothing necessarily intuitive or natural about this spatial mapping, the game was designed to mitigate the strangeness of navigating this artificial world rather than draw attention to its eccentricities.

Not all games follow this policy, and there are some exceptions to this rule. Even in The Legend of Zelda, there are two in-game locations that explicitly defy Cartesian cartography: the Lost Woods and the Lost Hills. When traveling through these single-screen mazes, Link finds himself endlessly looping, temporarily arrested by a classic gaming trope. Like Asteroids (1979) and Pacman (1980), if the player’s avatar crosses the edge of the screen, it appears immediately on the opposite side as if teleported instantly from one side of the level to the other. This looping effect is initially counterintuitive but becomes more and more naturalized as player’s adjust their spatial expectations to the particularities of each game-space.

The logic of each maze in The Legend of Zelda is relatively straightforward to program. A series of if statements dictate which sequence of directions lead Link out of each repeating landscape. Yet, the mathematical certainty and programmatic simplicity of the Lost Woods and Lost Hills generates visually complex topologies. Were a player to attempt to map the twists and turns Link traverses while rambling through the woods or hills, she would find the geometry of each maze would not cohere with the map of Hyrule. In this case, procedural and haptic logics do not render coherent visual schema. Whether the player realizes it or not, each looping space maps not to the flattened grid on which the rest of Hyrule is designed, but instead to the topology of a 3D torus (see Figure 5.) Recalling Hansen’s reading of skulls, it is possible for experienced players intuit the topology of the torus, but visualizing this space proves far more difficult.

figure.head: Screenshots of the Lost Woods and Lost Hills from The Legend of Zelda, with visualizations of each location in the form of a torus.

div.p: The games we will examine in this essay intentionally play within the dissonant registers produced between biological and computational systems. Their use of anamorphic techniques does not abandon the player to some raw, naked digital landscape (such an encounter, like an encounter with the Lacanian Real, would be impossible), but instead produces gameplay-metaphors that model an engagement with the concept of an unthinkable computational wildernesses. Moreover, they offer a fantasy of mastery through the successful completion of goal-oriented tasks and suggest that the body can be acclimated to these eccentric spaces. Flight simulators were developed to combat air sickness, and it is with a similar logic that anamorphic games invite players to test drive the digital ASW, to make it safe and naturalize the body to the incredible strangeness…odd tensing[s]…weird sensation[s] of a computer’s alien topography.

div.head: Introduction to Anamorphic Games
div.p: Although thousands of years have passed, the guiding principles of the gaming industry are not radically different from those which produced the lover’s silhouette or Zeuxis’ painted grapes. W.J.T. Mitchell’s Reconfigured Eye: Visual Truth in the Post-Photographic Era , for example, opens with Pliny’s birth of painting and draws a genealogical line from early optical experiments to contemporary digital imaging techniques. This path from Dürer’s glass perspectival grids to digital ray tracing is one to which the development of computer games has stubbornly stuck, largely propelled by the desire for realistic, immersive experiences. As Robert F. Nideffer pithily summarizes: Improved lighting, increasingly accurate physics models, and more believable artificial intelligence (AI) are seen as the next frontier for game engines by many in the industry. For anyone who attends meetings like the Game Developers Conference (GDC), the Electronic Entertainment Expo (E3), or SIGGRAPH, it quickly becomes apparent that these concerns are voiced almost exclusively from the desire to enhance the game world's realism.

Realism, in this case, refers to the ability to accurately represent mimetic detail as well as simulate a lived experience. Added to this privileging of graphic spectacle is an adherence to Hollywood’s narrative conventions, which frequently take precedence over aesthetic experimentation and the development of novel game mechanics. Thus, it is not realism or naturalism, but more specifically it is a filmic realism that defines the aesthetics of many recent commercial games. The emergence and celebration of the cut-scene in the late nineties is perhaps the most egregious way in which games have attempted to translate filmic storytelling into videogame narratives. A survey of the most anticipated games shown at this year’s E3 confirms that Nideffer’s observations continue to be applicable as mainstream games are dominated by Hollywood-style visual and narrative logic. The showpieces are comprised of games like Mass Effect 3, Modern Warfare 3, Battlefield 3, Uncharted 3, and Far Cry 3, which tempt players with the promise of the richest and most filmically immersive graphics on the market. The ubiquity of the series, as seen in the overwhelming number of game franchises, further demonstrates the conservative conditions under which mainstream games operate. There is generally less stigma attached to videogame sequels when compared to other media as both programmers and gamers alike seem to have a higher tolerance for seriality. The computational processes driving most games (and software at large) can be easily expanded, modified, and resold – there is always a substantial amount of exchange and appropriation in games at the level of code. Moreover, a game’s narrative is frequently regarded as peripheral to enjoyment of the software compared with modifications of gameplay. As a result, commercial studios are more reluctant to take million-dollar risks on untested intellectual property than simply revise an already-vetted formula when there is less pressure from the market to do so.

Amidst the production of Final Fantasy XIV and the annual Madden NFL, however, a transformation has occurred. The increased power of home computers and the availability of open source game engines and network toolsets have re-catalyzed the development of smaller-scale projects through user-generated content and modding, networked webgames, augmented and alternate reality game design, and mobile apps. The diffusion of the modes of production, the accessibility of design technologies, and the formation of a broader audience have inspired the development of experimental games that challenge more traditional genres. Now it is not uncommon to see games that frame themselves as meta-games, art games, countergames, antigames, overgames, endgames, and notgames.

The games discussed in this essay have been selected because they manipulate time, space, and physics in ways that draw attention not only to the formal logics of the computer, but also to how they situate and re-embody the player’s interaction with the game. The human body is tuned to intuitively negotiate the physics of time and space: crouching to avoid a low overhang or deftly catching balance after slipping on unstable terrain. But what happens to this proprioceptive capacity when encountering a hybridized space, a mixture of the actual and the virtual which contrasts embodied space-time with anamorphic algorithms? What if a body were required to negotiate two- and three-dimensional spaces simultaneously as with Sony’s Echochrome software? Can muscles remember the extra-dimensional abstractions overlaying Julian Oliver’s levelHead? And is it possible to simulate a fourth dimension as Mark ten Bosch’s Miegakure claims? These games offer the player simulations of a poetic physics, or what Bill Seaman has termed e-phany physics, namely the code-based authoring of an artificial physics which is consistent within the virtual space, yet does not adhere to the laws of actual physics . So what happens to the body when those laws of physics internalized since birth are re-written within these poetic simulations? The following videogames create interfaces to allegorize a space beyond the limits of human perception. Louis Althusser famously defined ideology as imaginary resolutions to real contradictions and these games attempt to resolve, hubristically, that absolute gulf that Hansen posits between digital space and human experience.

div.head: Echochrome: Depth Perception, Optical Architecture
div.p: When the first generation of home videogame consoles supporting 3D graphic processing was introduced in the mid-nineties, the development of 2D, sprite-based game development was temporarily arrested. This generation included notable systems like the Sega Saturn (1994), the Sony PlayStation (1994), and the Nintendo 64 (1996) which ran at least 32-bit graphic processors in order to render real time polygonal meshes which made up the perspectival spaces of 3D games. In the flush of fascination with these strange new polygonal spaces, the efforts of game designers were redirected from painting with pixels towards domesticating and naturalizing 3D environments for mainstream consumption (compared to earlier videogames, 3D games had a higher barrier to entry).

Nintendo’s transition from 2D to 3D games demonstrates the challenges of adjusting to these new spaces. Remembering the difficult launch of Super Mario 64 (1996), a release title for the Nintendo 64, Shigeru Miyamato remarked in a conversation with Nintendo’s CEO Satoru Iwata that [t]he reason that people felt distant to 3D action games was because those games were easy for some people to get motion sickness” and that it was “easy to get lost in the playing field . Hansen likens the feeling of the digital ASW to motion sickness and, in the case of videogames, this is precisely the medical condition a large number of uninitiated players experienced upon first exposure to 3D graphics. Despite the dramatic advancements that have been made in graphic processing technologies and audiences for such games have expanded, the difficulty of acclimatizing players to these spaces still remains. Even today, particularly amongst Japanese consumers, Nintendo's 2D titles consistently out-sell its 3D counterparts. Both Super Mario Galaxy (2007) and New Super Mario Bros. (2006), for example, were released around the same time and both were critically acclaimed; yet the side-scrolling platforming game sold two and a half times more copies than Super Mario Galaxy. Super Mario Galaxy was one of the first games to incorporate eccentric gravity and spherical levels into its design. In his interview with Miyamoto, Iwata comments, [A]t the time, I did not fully understand its benefits. I knew right away that visually [Super Mario Galaxy] would look great. But its true value was beyond what could be seen with the eyes, it was something that I hadn’t realized . Both Miyamoto's remark on motion sickness and Iwata’s observation on the way in which the effects of spherical space transcend optical effects indicate an awareness of how the body functions while playing these games. The visual is only a small part in a much more comprehensive bodily engagement with digital space.

In recent years, there has been a renaissance of 2D platforming games. The flatness of screen and 2D space is no longer a technological constraint, but a design decision which can be placed in conjunction with 3D spaces. One series of games which structures its gameplay around the intersection of two- and three-dimensional space and perspectival play is Sony’s Echo series consisting of Echochrome, Echochrome II, and Echoshift.

The first title, Echochrome, is produced by Sony's Japan Studio and Game Yarouze for the PlayStation Portable (PSP) and PlayStation 3 (PS3). In Echochrome the player is presented with a minimal, immaculately white space featuring one central object: a strange set of stairs, walkways, ramps, and ramparts reminiscent of M.C. Escher's impossible spaces and paradoxical architectures (see Figure 6). By twisting the joystick, this hovering level begins to rotate and, unlike a hand-drawn optical illusion, actually reconstitutes its perspectival paradoxes in real time. All the while, one solitary figure wanders back and forth, clacking footsteps resonating in empty space. The lone resident of these endless walkways is a textureless wooden mannequin who automatically strolls up and down the crisply contoured, isometric spaces inspired by M.C. Escher. Both the reference to Escher's artwork and the autonomous wooden mannequin, an object traditionally used for rendering perspectival figures, are fitting considering that the game’s main mechanic involves the player morphing strange spaces in ways that paradoxically play with the dichotomy between the representations of 3D rotations and the flat screen on which it is rendered.

figure.head: Images of Echochrome’s mannequin and level design.

div.p: There are five main rules to the pictorial logic governing the mannequin's movements through geometric space. These five perspectival laws, as presented in the official trailer, are: (1) When two separate pathways appear to be touching, they are. (2) If one pathway appears to be above another, it is. (3) When the gap between two pathways is blocked from view and the pathways appear to be connected, they are. (4) When a hole is blocked from view, it does not exist. (5) When the mannequin jumps, it will land on whatever appears beneath it .

Echochrome’s five rules all relate to the appearance of space as rendered to a flat image. Much like Nintendo's 2007 release of Super Paper Mario for the Nintendo Wii, Kuju Entertainment's Zoë Mode development studio's 2007 release of Crush for the PSP, and Polytron Corporation’s perennially forthcoming premier title, Fez, for XBLA, in the world of Echochrome, the three-dimensional architecture reflects and corroborates that which appears on the two-dimensional screen. In Echochrome, it is the pictorial logic of the screen that is given precedence over the mimetic representation of space. What you see is literally what you get.

Along with games such as Super Paper Mario, Crush, and Fez, Echochrome recalls Holbein’s The Ambassadors in the way it mixes traditional perspective with anamorphic effects. By self-consciously placing both two- and three-dimensional space in conversation with each other, the game conflates the dual logic of flat screen and deep window, two metaphors Anne Friedberg compares and contrasts in The Virtual Window: From Alberti to Microsoft . Friedberg argues that although perspective has historically been the culturally dominant form of visuality, computers have dramatically transformed how space is perceived and organized. She examines the graphic user interface of a computer desktop and the way it is composed of multiple, overlapping windows, conflicting light sources, and purely abstract drop shadows. Despite the fact that the window, which operating systems like Microsoft Windows provide, is overlooking a non-linear, non-perspectival vista, contemporary culture has adapted to this mode of spatial organization to the point that it appears as a continuous, uninterrupted space. Despite its mathematical artifice, Leon Battista Alberti famously described classical perspective as a window onto another world, and Friedberg demonstrates how computer software companies have appropriated similar rhetoric in order to naturalize what is a constructed, artificial space composed of many perspectival contradictions and incongruities. Terry Harpold also makes this observation in Ex-foliations: Reading Machines and the Upgrade Path when he examines the Bliss Screen of Windows XP, which included the default wallpaper of rolling grass and blue sky. Noting the uncanny connection between this pastoral imagery and Freud’s description of an alpine meadow in his 1899 essay Screen Memories, Harpold analyzes the advertising surrounding the release of the OS. One television commercial sets Madonna’s Ray of Light against images of euphoric Microsoft users diving through the screen in order to soar through (indistinguishable) physical and virtual spaces to the amazement of those looking on who have yet to test the GUI for themselves. The rhetoric of unmediated immersion and of a deep perspective, which the advertisement deploys in order to present the computer screen as a perspectival window, renders invisible the complex and contradictory non-linear visual organization that truly comprises the Windows GUI .

Echochrome stands out as a particularly intriguing example of an alternative spatial organization because it knowingly plays with the tension between pictorial and three-dimensional space. Echochrome insists that the player confront the contradictions of digital space rather than render them invisible or subordinate to the goals of user-friendliness or functionality. It is in this respect that Echochrome places itself in the same genealogical family as The Ambassadors. The Ambassadors, in fact, similarly illustrates the tension between material surface and illusionistic depth. Within the rhetoric of window and screen that Friedberg explores, one can imagine oneself looking through a virtual window onto the scene of two ambassadors standing beside each other. This fantasy is disrupted, however, through the presence of the smeared skull. The skull does not exist within the three-dimensional space of the painting, but instead appears as an object that is literally not of that world, or, as Hansen writes, an envoy from elsewhere . The fact that Holbein’s skull does not inhabit the same virtual plane is demonstrated by the fact that its shadows are not cast from the same light source. It is as if an imaginary pane of glass covers this window and the skull has been smeared over its transparent surface. There is a figure/ground oscillation as the painting moves between drawing attention to itself as a window as well as a screen. This hypermediated effect in which multiple lighting sources create layered windows into heterogeneous visual orders is the same visual logic at work in Echochrome.

In Echochrome, as the player rotates the central object in three-dimensions, the real-time graphic processes render the illusion of depth, the screen or monitor serving as virtual window. Near and far, broad and deep, at first Echochrome’s architecture appears to behave rationally, like a revolving showroom car or a piece of electronics on a turntable. However, when the collisions and connections of the Escher-esque architecture are ultimately determined according to the logic of the suspended two-dimensional image, the window into another realm flattens into an opaque screen.

Adjusting Echochrome’s perspective does not only transform the player’s view, but the structure of the architecture itself. The spatial dimensions and the composition of the object do not remain fixed in an absolute space. The architecture is reconstituted depending on the angle from which it is viewed. Much like The Ambassadors the game suggests that if the player positions herself correctly in front of the screen, the secret of solving the puzzle will be revealed. Discovering the solution to these levels, cracking their spatial code, is not unlike the idea that there exists a single viewing point from which The Ambassadors must be viewed in order to see the skull. This is also what separates Echochrome (and even The Ambassadors to some extent) from a work like skulls. The puzzle logic acts as an interface through which the player finds herself able to assume a naïve position of control and mastery of those perspectives that should otherwise be hopelessly unresolvable.

div.head: Echochrome II: Hand Puppets and Shadow Play
div.p: Echochrome creates a world built around the intersections of pictorial and three-dimensional space. Echochrome’s sequel, Echochrome II, once again plays with these rules, but, in addition to its predecessor’s uniquely hybrid perspective of both two- and three-dimensional objects, the sequel incorporates the play of light and shadow. Once again, what you see is what you get. The mannequin’s silhouette, referred to as the cast, must traverse visual puzzles via the player’s anamorphic manipulations of light. In Echochrome II, the cast does not walk along the physical objects, but along the shadowy, two-dimensional projected surfaces that fall in the wake of floating blocks, stairs, and steps (see Figure 7).

figure.head: An Echochrome II advertisement featuring interactive illumination.

div.p: Like its predecessor, Echochrome II is developed by Sony’s Japan Studio and made for PS3 but requires the PlayStation Move, a motion sensing hand controller spatially tracked by the PS Eye, Sony’s interactive infrared camera. The Sony Move is part of the latest generation of controllers for mainstream consoles and competes with other motion-control sensors such as the Wii Remote and the hands-free Kinect in which the Xbox 360 reads the physical gestures and voice commands of the player. These technologies call attention to the player’s body, situating them much more explicitly in a spatial relationship to the games being played. Unlike The Ambassadors and skulls which shock the human body by highlighting the tension between the virtual and the physical, these controllers attempt to suture the two realities together in a way that appears natural or intuitive. The Move controller is topped by a glowing sphere that flickers and changes colors when the wand is active, emitting infrared light for the PS Eye (see Figure 8). This motion tracking technology inverts the relationship between controller and camera pioneered by the Nintendo Wii, which emits two infrared points of light from a stationary bar set near the screen and received by a camera within the Wii Remote (see Figure 8). In Echochrome II, this light-tracking technology is used to literally position the in-game light source which, when cast on the floating objects, produces virtual shadows in real time based on the player’s bodily gestures. These motions translate into the computational space surprisingly well as the player shines the Move controller on her television screen like a digitized flashlight. Rays are traced from the tip of the wand at the precise angle of incidence, rays which pierce multiple realities to simulate light sources for in-game objects and architectures.

figure.head: A comparison of Sony’s PlayStation Move and Nintendo’s Wii Remote.

div.p: While videogames like Hideo Kojima’s Metal Gear Solid series (1998–present) revolutionized stealth mechanics by extending the physicality of in-game characters to include their footsteps, blood trails, ambient sounds, odor, and, of course, shadows, other games like Fumito Ueda’s Ico (2001) pits the player against impressionistic shadow beasts, dwelling in the dark corners of high citadels and deep dungeons. Shadows have long been generated in videogames to both establish mise-en-scène and shape the mood of virtual settings, enhancing graphic realism and general legibility through the addition of naturalistic details. Recently, however, a number of games have re-cast the shadow, moving it from the background to become either an overarching aesthetic style or core game mechanic. Within the last year, for example, Playdead’s Limbo (2010) and Hudson’s Lost in Shadow (2011) exploit shadowy imagery to represent the wandering souls of lost children. In Limbo and Lost in Shadow, flat, boyish avatars traverse perverted silhouettes of everyday life in search of their missing bodies (see Figure 9). They are shades caught in monotone netherworlds. The visual rhetoric employed by these two games is reminiscent of fairytales featuring magic mirrors, crystal balls, and wishing wells – cautionary tales of reflection, refraction, and other tricks of light.

figure.head: Screenshots comparing the shadowy avatars in both Limbo and Lost in Shadow.

div.p: Continuing this minor tradition of shadow play, the more experimental offerings from the independent developers producing Closure (forthcoming) and Unfinished Swan (forthcoming) focus on shadows as their main game mechanic. In the Flash-turning-console game Closure, a puzzle platformer which follows Echochrome’s what-you-see-is-what-you-get logic, designers Jon Schubbe and Tyler Glaiel program onscreen objects that physically persist only if illuminated. In the procedural architecture of Closure blackness is nothingness – any unlit object simply ceases to exist allowing the childlike player-character to tiptoe through dimly lit walls and tumble through shadows cast on the floor. Closure recalls the aesthetic of Edward Gorey’s Gashlycrumb Tinies (1963), a gruesome alphabet book which poetically describes how a group of children met their untimely deaths (e.g. N is for Neville who died of ennui) and, like Limbo, follows lone children through Purgatory (see Figure 10). Following the conventions of the other two games, Schubbe and Glaiel present a child’s-eye view of a world turned black and white, a world in which anamorphic light and shadow distort physical reality. Like the reader of Gashlycrumb Tinies, the player uncovers the many ways in which she can plunge into nothingness.

figure.head: A comparison of the Gashlycrumb aesthetic and indie game Closure.

div.p: Lying at the opposite end of the color spectrum, The Unfinished Swan is an experimental prototype developed by Giant Sparrow. The game is a first-person shooter set in a field of blinding whiteness. Luckily, the player wields a kind of paint or shadow gun used to differentiate the otherwise invisible geometry of each level as one progresses (see Figure 11). In both Closure and The Unfinished Swan, 3D space and the architecture therein does not exist without some form of anamorphic shading.

figure.head: Early screenshot from the forthcoming Unfinished Swan.

div.p: The philosophy of these games hinges on the popular idea that light forms an index of a fixed material reality, and the play of shadows on an uneven surface reveals the deeply anamorphic properties of light. Truth is never resolved and always distorted. Like the possibility of Butades’ daughter revealing the wicked or grotesque, shadowy side of her lover by miscasting his image in the fading light, the digital shadows of Limbo, Lost in Shadow, and even Echochrome II engage time-tested cultural myths as a way of thinking about the computer in general. If Mark Hansen’s digital ASW is activated by the friction between biological and technical systems, then the anamorphic shadow play depicted in these popular games should function to remind the user of the ubiquity of deception. These shadowy reminders are not simply a new generation of memento mori - though, in the case of Limbo, Lost in Shadow, and Closure, depictions of Purgatory certainly conjure the spectre of death. No, these games are more related to Hans Holbein’s stretched skull, a memento mori shot through with the logics of technological alterity. Because computerized shadow play of this sort aestheticizes the uncomfortable feelings of the digital ASW through morbid imagery of death, it reminds the viewer not of her mortality, but of the limits of human experience in general: a memento mortem mortis. This digital memento mortem mortis carves out a space not for death, but the death of death - a reminder that beyond consciousness there exist fields of experience altogether indifferent to the human.

Though it lacks the pallor of the previously discussed titles, Echochrome II is also ranked among these games which make the maneuvering of shadows a core game mechanic. The shadows produced by the Move recall the flickering lamp flame in Pliny’s story of Butades, but rather than assume a visual symmetry between silhouette and object (the way in which this myth has been almost universally depicted in various paintings), the game reveals the dissonance and distortions that prevail in the world of shadows. In Echochrome II, the player can adjust the light source in order to form a kind of anamorphic shadow art. Similar to Holbein’s skull, if a viewer positioned the light source at a particular angle, the game will reveal hidden, albeit banal, images (e.g. a smiley face or snake, etc.) (see Figure 12). Just as Butades took the silhouette traced by his daughter to cast a sculpture, the shadows of Echochome II serve as a conflation of silhouette and sculpture. These digital-born shadow puppets operate according to the pictorial logic of two-dimensional shadow play, but also have the geometrical space of a three-dimensional model. The shadow that is cast by the player’s control of the flashlight is not modeled with clay, but with polygons and assigned an autonomous physics and materiality from the original object. The Echochrome series invites the player to haptically engage with this de-realized space and to not take their physical position with respect to the screen for granted. The glowing orb substitutes for the player’s eyeball, as the player learns how to alter the angle of the light source in order to achieve a mastery (albeit naïve) over distorted, anamorphic images.

div.head: levelHead: A Multi-Dimensional Memory Palace
div.p: Echochrome II is designed to function with (and market) a specific commercial remote: Sony’s PlayStation Move. The most recent generation of console controllers, inspired by the success of Nintendo’s unconventional Wii Remote, has challenged the joystick-button and mouse-keyboard input combinations previously taken for granted as the industry standard. Though the advertising surrounding these products, fueled by the naïve desire for heightened immersivity, boasts the most streamlined and transparent forms of interactivity, this certainly does not mean players are freed from constraints. Even Microsoft’s Kinect, a hands free human interface device which is able to track real-time 3D video using a grid of infrared laser beams, reinforces the schism between screen and embodied space as it is less responsive and more opaque in terms of how gestures are translated to onscreen commands. The irony at the heart of these aspirations towards increased immersivity is articulated in Mark Hansen’s theory of the digital ASW, which claims that biological entities are always somewhat sensitive to the disruptive phenomenal effects of computational systems. Because artworks like Lazzarini’s skulls are designed around the bodily tension one experiences in the face of digital media, they offer a stern critique of the very possibility of immersion. Subscribing to this design ideology, independent artist Julian Oliver has designed both a game and controller which do not take standard forms of interaction for granted.

In 2007, Oliver created levelHead, an interactive video installation to be displayed in museums and galleries or on home computers via open source software (see Figure 13). The installation combines color-coded and patterned cubes with the custom software which, via a small webcam, tracks and replaces the six unique facets of each cube with three-dimensional, interactive architecture appearing to fill the space inside the cube given the angle of view. The result is a large real-time video projection that displays the player's hands interfacing with the virtualized cubes. The cubes serve as controllers, and, like Echochrome and especially Echochrome II, the player's physical gestures and positioning change the virtual viewpoint and guide a small, white, humanoid silhouette through a six-sided interior architecture. This unassuming avatar, like the minimally-designed cast featured in the Echochrome series, simply follows the path of least resistance based on the angle at which a user holds each cube. By tilting each cube, the player indirectly guides the avatar instead of interacting directly as is more common in games. Not coincidentally, levelHead’s avatar is figured as an automaton or dummy, a lost soul wandering aimlessly through shifting architecture. The cubes work in sequence, each containing six unique rooms overlaid inside the same internal space for a total of eighteen rooms. By tracking objects and actions instead of interfacing with standardized controller input and projecting the results back on that which is being sampled, Oliver’s game extends the virtual space of the screen to the physical environment.

LevelHead presents the inside of the cube as if it were a shadowbox, but when the player adjusts the side of the cube facing the camera, an entirely different architectural space appears. Difficulty and tension arise from the fact that the player must imagine six simultaneous spaces within the singular geometry of the box twisting in her hand. Each two-dimensional surface becomes a window to a different three-dimensional space. The challenge of this game, as Oliver has written, lies in having to remember the spatial organization of the rooms despite the fact that they are not simultaneously present to the viewer or interconnected in a way that is physically possible. The logic of the cube’s architecture, therefore, must be constructed out of a different set of haptic cues, engaging with the wrist and hand:

The tangible interface aspect becomes integral to the function of recall also: as the cube is turned by the hands in search of correctly adjoining rooms muscle-memory is engaged and, as such, aids the memory as a felt memory of patterns of turns: that room is two turns to the left when this room is upside down .

Although Oliver offers a walkthrough available on Youtube, he notes that the game is very difficult and, given the two-minute time limit to finish each puzzle, it is doubtful many have fully toured what Oliver calls the apartment . Thus, for the vast majority of players, engagement with levelHead produces a response similar to Hansen’s description of skulls.

When holding the level heads, hands and wrists quickly organize each cube into a coherent program which does not comply with what the eyes see. As Oliver points out, the body grounds the player’s frame of reference, yet she is placed in a space removed from standard forms of orientation, and there is a disconnect between what the player feels holding the solid cube and what she sees projected. The incommensurability between haptic and optical feedback recalls skulls. Were a viewer to close her eyes and place her hands on the skulls, the objects would still resolve to the touch, yet the visual anamorphic distortions throw off the viewer’s equilibrium to produce what Hansen describes as the feeling of a digital ASW. LevelHead makes a game out of negotiating haptic orientation with a visual and cognitive disorientation.

This process is a good example of what Andy Clark and David J. Chalmers described as the externalization of thought. The expression the left hand doesn’t know what the right hand is doing is a common saying, but when it comes to gaming, neurological experiments have discovered that the expression should more accurately be that the conscious mind does not know what the hands are doing. Clark and Chalmers cite a 1994 study by David Kirsh and Paul Maglio in which participants were asked to play the game Tetris, using a controller to rotate the shape to ascertain the ideal slot into which the block should be placed . A second test group was asked to visualize the same action without an interface, haptic or otherwise. What they discovered was that, enabled by environmental as well as bodily support, the brain was able to process the information far more efficiently. Using a controller, participants were able to perform the operation in 300 milliseconds (200 milliseconds to press a button, then 100 milliseconds for the screen to refresh) while it took around 1000 milliseconds for the same result to be achieved mentally. These findings suggest that cognition exceeds not only the mind, but the hand as well, consciousness co-developing in concert with body and environment.

Games like levelHead dramatize the externalization of thought, compelling the player to not only rethink the way in which she processes space, but also her haptic engagement with this alternative visual regime. Recalling the findings of Kirsh and Maglio’s Tetris study, Oliver’s game is constructed with an awareness of how vision is dependent on the rest of the body and external apparatuses. As he emphasizes in an artist statement, the muscle memory of the hand is indispensable for successful navigation of the game’s paradoxical space. While seasoned players are acutely aware of the operation of muscle memory, the design of most games still relies on a model of autonomous visual memory (i.e. observing a space enables us to orient and then move within it). This is one of the unique aspects of levelHead which does not take hand, body, or cube-controller for granted or treat them mainly as instruments for executing orders. Oliver’s game is built around the assumption that all the interactions within this cybernetic system are a necessary pre-condition for comprehending and traversing the environment.

The Tetris study erodes the Cartesian model of mind/body dualism, demonstrating a distributed model of cognition that puts pressure on the question of where the body stops and the rest of the world begins. What is also notable about this example of situated cognition is the fact that it is based around a cognitive aporia. The incommensurable gulf between the processes of a computer and the embodied engagement of the human is also a precondition for the cybernetic system to function: the hyphen in human-computer interaction signifying this chasm. If the left hand does not know what the right is doing, the corollary to this is that it cannot know what the machine does either. Thus Oliver’s level heads tilt and twist into versions of the smeared skull, challenging the player to peer into an irresolvable and paradoxical architecture. Clutching this existential object, another memento mortem mortis, the player glimpses into a space beyond human thought, beyond the anxious debates of “to be or not to be” into a dimension where these questions are rendered insignificant and objects historically designed to expose and critique human vanitas are themselves turned into displays of anthropocentric vanity and narcissism.

div.head: Miegakure: A Garden of Many Forking Dimensions
div.p: By creating an imaginary space in which six interconnected rooms co-exist within the same three-dimensional space, the game inverts the standard notion of projection and plays with a kind of fourth-dimensional logic. In the physical world, the projection of a three-dimensional object will produce a two-dimensional image. By contrast, levelHead produces a reverse-projection as the flat surface of the side of the cube is converted into a three-dimensional virtual world. Recently smartphones have begun to develop augmented reality software and applications more widely which project a three-dimensional image over a two-dimensional screen. Much like levelHead, physical and virtual worlds overlap within a hybrid space. The Nintendo 3DS, a portable game console which features a glasses-free 3D screen, has also released augmented reality games in which a player positions the camera of the console over machine-readable images. The player sees three-dimensional objects placed over the video of her surroundings, which are also subject to manipulation and distortions rendered in real-time. In the virtual space of the screen, these three-dimensional rooms exist within the same cube, overlapping each other. Although only one room is seen at a time, the player can imagine the cube functioning like a tesseract or hypercube. The player must imagine six three-dimensional cubes contained within the cube she holds in her hand, although only one set of three-dimensional coordinates is observable at any time. These rooms simulate a fourth-dimensional space. This conceptual abstraction functions as a rhetorical device which stands in for a player’s actual encounter with the alien and inaccessible ontology of the everyday technological objects with which we surround ourselves. Anamorphosis becomes a means to aestheticize this encounter with what Ian Bogost has called the alien phenomenology of the computer, which we will discuss further below.

While levelHead’s disorienting architecture has an implied fourth dimensional physics, there are games being developed such as Marc ten Bosch’s Miegakure: A Garden in Four Dimensions which directly incorporate fourth dimensional theory into their platforming game design. Whereas the Echochrome series and levelHead experiment by creating a spatial regime in which the laws of two- and three-dimensional perspective overlap with each other, Miegakure adds another dimension to create a puzzle platform game that thinks in four dimensions (see Figure 14). While the fourth dimension is impossible for the human mind to visualize, it can be easily represented mathematically. The expanse between what is possible to represent in mathematics and what can be humanly imagined, is the reason why Quentin Meillassoux coins the expression the great outdoors in After Finitude. Rather than thinking of the great outdoors in terms of a Caspar David Friedrich painting, which situates a human subject amongst the overwhelming sublimity of nature, Meillassoux uses the expression to refer to a universe that persists beyond the boundaries of human knowability: [t]his is the enigma which we must confront: mathematics' ability to discourse about the great outdoors; to discourse about a past where both humanity and life are absent .

figure.head: Screenshots from Mark ten Bosch’s forthcoming Miegakure

div.p: The fourth dimension is one such space where the abstractions of math and physics, but not humans, may venture. Thus, faced with the paradox of representing the non-representable, ten Bosch’s strategy is to create a computational space in which each three-dimensional coordinate contains not three, but four points of information representing four possible dimensions in space and, as ten Bosch writes on his website, at the press of a button one of the dimensions is exchanged with the fourth dimension, allowing for four-dimensional movement . Thus, a block situated within a three-dimensional grid will appear to magically smear by removing one coordinate and substituting it for the hidden fourth coordinate. Mathematically, one can make n-dimensional objects simply by adding more coordinates alongside the traditional designations for width, height, and depth. What exists as a computational abstraction cannot be visually modeled on the two-dimensional screen, yet the process of substitution simulates the traversal between alternate sets of data representing dimensions. The caveat to both Miegakure and Lazzarini’s skulls is that the player never engages directly with an extra-dimensional space. These works do not provide, as Lacan suggested of anamorphic imagery, a glimpse into the Real, but rather continue to signify and speculate on the impossibility of doing so.

This, however, is not what ten Bosch argues, somewhat hubristically proposing that games grant access to the fourth dimension, allowing players to experience it first-hand, using trial and error, as opposed to being told about it . Miegakure extends the fantasy of being able to colonize and control fourth-dimensional space. But the deeper significance that will ultimately be gained from the game is not a “first-hand” knowledge of the fourth dimension, but the computational processes, what Ian Bogost terms the “procedural rhetoric” of the game [Bogost 2007, 28–29]. And it is in this respect that Miegakure uses the fantasy of traversing the inaccessible fourth dimension as a metaphor for traversing the equally inaccessible computational processes of a computer. The gameplay of Miegakure recalls Hansen’s claim about skulls and the way in which the anamorphic space stands in for the weird logic and topology of the computer . Miegakure and other games that experiment with eccentric spatial and temporal regimes suggest that the inside of a computer is as strange and mysterious as the fourth dimension and that both exceed human capacities of comprehension.

In Gaming: Essays on Algorithmic Culture , Alexander Galloway has persuasively argued that videogames are allegories of control; they are cultural objects which rhetorically present themselves as the source of freedom, yet in doing so they conceal the protocological network of continuous informatic control under which individuals now live . Computer games ultimately subsume the player within a strict system of rules that allegorize contemporary informatic culture at large. One might further add that videogames function not only as allegories of control, but allegories of the beyond. By presenting a set of computational processes as rules for organizing play, videogames invite players to learn the limits and affordances of a game-space. To play a game is to test the system, to uncover (and be uncovered by) the codes that will allow for successful execution of in-game commands. In this way, play is co-developed through a mutual enterprise of becoming computational. Miegakure’s attempt to visualize the fourth spatial dimension is particularly apt because the fourth set of coordinates the game actually visualizes engage with the same problematic: the limit of human perception. By attempting to colonize computational space through the insertion of a human subjectivity, Miegakure adopts the ambitious premise that the formal topology of computational space can be manipulated, controlled, and conquered (when, as Galloway observes, videogames in fact excel at accomplishing the opposite). Ten Bosch’s game simulates the insertion of human agency into a place in which it does not belong.

Miegakure uses a fourth set of 3D coordinates as a metaphor and simulation of fourth dimensional space. This does not allow the player access to actual fourth dimensional physics, yet the parallel between computational and fourth-dimensional space is apt as both engage with the same problematic: the limit of human perception. By attempting to colonize computational space through the insertion of a human subjectivity, Miegakure adopts the ambitious premise that the formal topology of the computer can be manipulated, controlled, and conquered (when, as Galloway observes, videogames in fact excel at accomplishing the opposite). Ten Bosch’s game simulates the insertion of human agency into a place that it does not belong.

Miegakure, ten Bosch clarifies, is Japanese for hide and reveal and refers to a specific gardening technique used in Japan. The game is set within a Japanese Zen garden, evoking a space of contemplation and relaxation as the player ponders mathematical abstractions and inter-dimensional ontologies. Like Mark Z. Danielewski’s House of Leaves, the gardening technique conjures a space which is paradoxically larger on the inside than the outside. The objects in the garden interweave with one another and expand through multiple dimensions. The gardening metaphor is particularly apt because a garden not only represents a space of contemplation, but one of control and the domestication of nature. Ten Bosch's game similarly represents an attempt to domesticate a computational wilderness, to seize the great outdoors, and till the land such that it falls back under the purview of human authority.

div.head: Alien Phenomenology and the Entelechy of the Weird
div.p: The fascination with a computational wilderness, the great outdoors of digital space, is what game scholar Ian Bogost has developed into a philosophy he calls alien phenomenology.
